You have to be in a directory that has a configure script
When you're in the source directory where configure exists, ./configure will run that configure script in that directory
The key is, you have to be in the same directory that configure script is in when you run ./configure
And you should never use root to build source
or to do any user tasks (such as configuring building source)
You probably screwed up the permissions by using root in the first place
It's a really bad idea
For one thing, it's a security issue. And you should not form a habit of using sudo or root because linux is permissions based
If you start running user apps as root, it could foil your permissions and then you can have other problems latert
configuring and building source are not administrative tasks. Installing the built project into standard prefix on the filesystem is however
You shouldn't run anything as root unless you understand why you need superuser privileges
